title: Narrative Studies in Interdisciplinary Perspective: Theories, Methodologies and Revisions
abstractText:
The ‘narrative turn’ has become a marked feature of the contemporary zeitgeist, from bio-pics to popular biographies to video diaries to the resurgence of interest in auto/biographical methods in the humanities and social sciences. Narrative Studies includes a diverse range of theories and methodologies; and while some approaches lay claim to canonical position, in general it remains open, flexible and attendant to overlaps and convergences as much as conflicts and divergences, a large part of its attraction for many.

This ESRC Seminar Series will facilitate exploration of core concerns, including conflicts as well as agreements; in Narrative Studies, promote interdisciplinary dialogue across ‘conventional’ disciplinary boundaries; include scholars and practitioners from a wide range of inter/national contexts; and encompass graduate students and RAs as well as established scholars.

  • The narrative turn: revisioning theory - 1 December 2006
  • Organisational practices & testimonial narratives of ‘other’ lives - 23 March 2007
  • Narrative and the documents of life: everybody’s autobiography? - 7 September 2007
  • Space, place, time: body narratives and performance - 14 December 2007
  • Past, present and future: auto/biography, national narratives and social change - 14 March 2008
  • Narrative studies to 2020: modes and methodologies - 13 June 2008
